document.title: Department for Education, English programmes of study: key stages 1 and 2, National curriculum in England, September 2013

575B3E65BBF24D5FAD99B5DE9802F692.description: punctuation, full stop, question mark, exclamation mark

FE03F8808D3542578A0F83AEC1AF934D.description: Capital letters for names and for the personal pronoun I

13E1CFF9089A428DB6CE06EE0EB90E1F.description:
Introduction to capital letters, full stops, question marks and exclamation
marks to demarcate sentences

E68AE7D4F2AA4D46B8352E7F5149A226.description: Sequencing sentences to form short narratives

366545A994F94DF4996AF54E5186C82A.description: Joining words and joining clauses using and

95C92C46C18842EFACB7D8E25D2F78EA.description: How words can combine to make sentences

8365C2D8C6C0430A8BB8ABE2D5E56DDA.description: How the prefix un– changes the meaning of verbs and adjectives [negation, for example, unkind, or undoing: untie the boat]

4A7BCCB17FC64500B4E88E90CF9295C8.description: Suffixes that can be added to verbs where no change is needed in the spelling of root words (e.g. helping, helped, helper)

BD0E86C5B1084CCB8BC8F68F485AC5BC.description: Regular plural noun suffixes –s or –es [for example, dog, dogs; wish, wishes], including the effects of these suffixes on the meaning of the noun

F5C09B30FC9B43F5B523E176E0B34D97.description: Common exception words [Pupils’ attention should be drawn to the grapheme- phoneme correspondences that do and do not fit in with what has been taught so far.] {the, a, do, to, today, of, said, says, are, were, was, is, his, has, I, you, your, they, be, he, me, she, we, no, go, so, by, my, here, there, where, love, come, some, one, once, ask, friend, school, put, push, pull, full, house, our – and/or others, according to the programme used}

78FC115BA25747338F9FCD025FF114DF.description: Compound words [Compound words are two words joined together. Each part of the longer word is spelt as it would be if it were on its own.] {football, playground, farmyard, bedroom, blackberry}

0C5A47F36BE54275B504168F6799A61B.description: Adding the prefix –un [The prefix un– is added to the beginning of a word without any change to the spelling of the root word.] {unhappy, undo, unload, unfair, unlock}

642FDEBCE06243AE9AE17E29E5D33F93.description: Using k for the /k/ sound [The /k/ sound is spelt as k rather than as c before e, i and y.] {Kent, sketch, kit, skin, frisky}

E53E68845D994AC086130A1B75D9BDFB.description: New consonant spellings ph and wh [The /f/ sound is not usually spelt as ph in short everyday words (e.g. fat, fill, fun).] {dolphin, alphabet, phonics, elephant when, where, which, wheel, while}

18749703636741669E5C5EEFCE8D8F88.description: Words ending –y (/i:/ or /ɪ/) {very, happy, funny, party, family}

196F423BBEFB4A3AA9702FA51C5DD855.description: ie (/aɪ/) {lie, tie, pie, cried, tried, dried}

B93A1DDE030440E08964C13BFD410586.description:
ow (/aʊ/) ow (/əʊ/) ue
ew [Both the /u:/ and /ju:/ (‘oo’ and ‘yoo’) sounds can be spelt as u–e, ue and ew. If words end in the /oo/ sound, ue and ew are more common spellings than oo.] {now, how, brown, down, town own, blow, snow, grow, show blue, clue, true, rescue, Tuesday new, few, grew, flew, drew, threw}

F92F0C3FA49445A497537950BAFA61C4.description: ou [The only common English word ending in ou is you.] {out, about, mouth, around, sound}

255B638423CF44059A9D413ABB8D2BA0.description: oa [The digraph oa is very rare at the end of an English word.] {boat, coat, road, coach, goal}

91982626CB534FEEBA6336D0184AC91F.description: oo (/u:/) [Very few words end with the letters oo, although the few that do are often words that primary children in year 1 will encounter, for example, zoo] {food, pool, moon, zoo, soon}

95E03B97AE32473682D4E2CD970516C9.description: er (/ə/) {(unstressed schwa sound): better, under, summer, winter, sister}

5D0B4899D59443AB9F6DC70E57AB4461.description: er (/ɜ:/) {(stressed sound): her, term, verb, person}

A1B7CF86EF60402DB007FDC6E2DE496D.description: ea (/ɛ/) {head, bread, meant, instead, read (past tense)}

46D749772D644AA9BEA883D92EC07E47.description: ea (/i:/) {sea, dream, meat, each, read (present tense)}

F41E01403688471B9996D6FB1067CA24.description: u-e [Both the /u:/ and /ju:/ (‘oo’ and ‘yoo’) sounds can be spelt as u–e.] {June, rule, rude, use, tube, tune}

D729341711B6448EB2B0694717D88DF2.description: ay, oy [ay and oy are used for those sounds at the end of words and at the end of syllables.] {day, play, say, way, stay boy, toy, enjoy, annoy}

1521DD2680CD41C38B70660552B71C1D.description: ai, oi [The digraphs ai and oi are virtually never used at the end of English words.] {rain, wait, train, paid, afraid oil, join, coin, point, soil}

FC395E81357740668ECA6E4F579B8D17.description: Adding –er and –est to adjectives where no change is needed to the root word [As with verbs (see above), if the adjective ends in two consonant letters (the same or different), the ending is simply added on.] {grander, grandest, fresher, freshest, quicker, quickest}

1616EE871D41400C888BB688C1F36F6C.description: Adding s and es to words (plural of nouns and the third person singular of verbs) [If the ending sounds like /s/ or /z/, it is spelt as –s. If the ending sounds like /ɪz/ and forms an extra syllable or ‘beat’ in the word, it is spelt as –es.] {cats, dogs, spends, rocks, thanks, catches}

A0A6BCE650A54D499BCB9FF9B614E8C0.description: The /v/ sound at the end of words [English words hardly ever end with the letter v, so if a word ends with a /v/ sound, the letter e usually needs to be added after the ‘v’.] {have, live, give}

165F8C354213456E806F6BF26E64B658.description: -tch [The /tʃ/ sound is usually spelt as tch if it comes straight after a single vowel letter. Exceptions: rich, which, much, such.] {catch, fetch, kitchen, notch, hutch}

0AAE18ECF3C04CE5A58F3FA5C072A0BD.description: Division of words into syllables [Each syllable is like a ‘beat’ in the spoken word. Words of more than one syllable often have an unstressed syllable in which the vowel sound is unclear.] {pocket, rabbit, carrot, thunder, sunset}

8834DD7B41154BC4AF42C12B985668BD.description: The /ŋ/ sound spelt n before k {bank, think, honk, sunk}

24484273B9FA47599B84F7ADF6D4020B.description: The sounds /f/, /l/, /s/, /z/ and /k/ spelt ff, ll, ss, zz and ck [The /f/, /l/, /s/, /z/ and /k/ sounds are usually spelt as ff, ll, ss, zz and ck if they come straight after a single vowel letter in short words. Exceptions: if, pal, us, bus, yes.] {off, well, miss, buzz, back}

3197AF2DFFE243A8A645ED7794B0E193.description: guidance and rules which have been taught

9AFC12B9749B4EE5B4B107E844B2B418.description: the process of segmenting spoken words into sounds before choosing graphemes to represent the sounds

6C32C59333054D0F9B70079DD6661770.description: vowel digraphs which have been taught and the sounds which they represent

8EC445A178394A55BF8672B4CFE3EC6F.description: consonant digraphs which have been taught and the sounds which they represent

5353BF4BF7B54DD786217323F8EA15DB.description: all letters of the alphabet and the sounds which they most commonly represent

6F40E829F43E4028A1E8973E06B5B527.description: use the grammatical terminology in English Appendix 2 in discussing their writing

A715402F1DC143C1B8EE0429DD8C8755.description: learning the grammar for year 1 in English Appendix 2

C5C5FC5F845E44B2B772DD1E5DA43061.description: using a capital letter for names of people, places, the days of the week, and the personal pronoun ‘I’

0DA44A9D1827469EA149C6CECEDE4D6E.description: beginning to punctuate sentences using a capital letter and a full stop, question mark or exclamation mark

C884F9C4D64149D78B2C765E6459B37C.description: joining words and joining clauses using and

A1DBC361808E4273923F63D9EAC5E178.description: develop their understanding of the concepts set out in English Appendix 2 by:

9219294022CC47BCB139CA30CF3F94F2.description: read aloud their writing clearly enough to be heard by their peers and the teacher

4785D9F1D3A64A31BECC39C0208CBB97.description: discuss what they have written with the teacher or other pupils

12C7F17D65B548AC90E48979DBF5287D.description: re-reading what they have written to check that it makes sense

69EF2EEED6474875B7797DA32843703F.description: sequencing sentences to form short narratives

A728243A1FCA40F6BFBA3755DE26368F.description: composing a sentence orally before writing it

25B9BD5DDE204897B7B8564CAECDB84D.description: saying out loud what they are going to write about

D85B798EEFB2436EA8F67F0E776CCF33.description: understand which letters belong to which handwriting ‘families’ (i.e. letters that are formed in similar ways) and to practise these

445C3611F39A414D99F2C8B890E47F19.description: begin to form lower-case letters in the correct direction, starting and finishing in the right place

8B9E0CA9C17D48238F29B7CE1C1172F9.description: sit correctly at a table, holding a pencil comfortably and correctly

40A253CEE696422CBA2A6BEAEB2FBCCE.description: write from memory simple sentences dictated by the teacher that include words using the GPCs and common exception words taught so far

B427AE37E21F4CD4BFD244FAA9CE2A61.description: apply simple spelling rules and guidance, as listed in English Appendix 1

846EF86D516B47C7B549C0CA3996DF5A.description: add prefixes and suffixes, using –ing, –ed, –er and –est where no change is needed in the spelling of root words [for example, helping, helped, helper, eating, quicker, quickest]

DE0FD38CFE454C93A5DD3C4E440197B1.description: add prefixes and suffixes, using the prefix un–

A15432E495904CB9A5B6BFF68A8CCBE6.description:
add prefixes and suffixes,
  using the spelling rule for adding –s or –es as the plural marker for nouns and
the third person singular marker for verbs

BE7575AB5569478B8CBD4BB1610FB77D.description: name the letters of the alphabet, using letter names to distinguish between alternative spellings of the same sound

6D5B6CDED9AF49D4BEB29AC007E17F44.description: name the letters of the alphabet, naming the letters of the alphabet in order

50C4505C25AE4F20A8FF0850011164AF.description: name the letters of the alphabet:

E97EC66C29944F16908E54D162449CB3.description: spell the days of the week

EA0A72D9B8DA4B2EBAB6C5883630AEF2.description: spell words containing each of the 40+ phonemes already taught

B6DB7AA2252A40FB9BDFC699DA233C1C.description: explain clearly their understanding of what is read to them

3DCE1BE11A2046CD9ABFC1AA8C4ACB62.description: participate in discussion about what is read to them, taking turns and listening to what others say

6EEA92337AA84D63B4A1126656987737.description: predicting what might happen on the basis of what has been read so far

0E46298F62544AEAA84123009D44E4E1.description: making inferences on the basis of what is being said and done

93CE550FB6ED47B497783AD341D72BB2.description: discussing the significance of the title and events

17873A313A23470D80E5D3DFF9F02347.description: checking that the text makes sense to them as they read and correcting inaccurate reading

E39A3E043C8B4F95B85C6B0CC26DF53C.description: drawing on what they already know or on background information and vocabulary provided by the teacher

590DE13F4CC848768C69F7C043288ECE.description: understand both the books they can already read accurately and fluently and those they listen to by:

20CCC818DDA24E19A50EFCA33B852CF2.description: discussing word meanings, linking new meanings to those already known

A5F5FB3DC4B24EB5B828CFEEF741BC1C.description: learning to appreciate rhymes and poems, and to recite some by heart

75F985A3ABB744309FFB17EE916500E2.description: recognising and joining in with predictable phrases

AD014813B3B24D79B6062C230AE15E02.description:
becoming very familiar with key stories, fairy stories and traditional tales,
retelling them and considering their particular characteristics

DC9F2D59190C4FB2A9F346B73409DCF7.description: being encouraged to link what they read or hear read to their own experiences

557057CF88A4423288B5CC0E1661A071.description: listening to and discussing a wide range of poems, stories and non-fiction at a level beyond that at which they can read independently

7E06333E20864804ABE3CADAB6662E70.description: develop pleasure in reading, motivation to read, vocabulary and understanding by:

ECD0BF99C87145FC8345D64234B25A4B.description: re-read these books to build up their fluency and confidence in word reading

016936C42F5646FCB648D8D869BC8571.description: read aloud accurately books that are consistent with their developing phonic knowledge and that do not require them to use other strategies to work out words

A0D6D38C0A0D4C12865AF6D995A35BC7.description: read words with contractions [for example, I’m, I’ll, we’ll], and understand that the apostrophe represents the omitted letter(s)

8928F5B772FA4E3A81E30AAF992C9ABD.description: read other words of more than one syllable that contain taught GPCs

949AAAF50A404DE69CF4B05CE6F85A59.description: read words containing taught GPCs and –s, –es, –ing, –ed, –er and –est endings

795CC9D5FD8246CF93DE8A53ACE99D55.description: read common exception words, noting unusual correspondences between spelling and sound and where these occur in the word

EA3FE373E772422EB9152FF27408C3EF.description: read accurately by blending sounds in unfamiliar words containing GPCs that have been taught

ACC5D873DBB34F6AB94442FC81E9AD86.description: respond speedily with the correct sound to graphemes (letters or groups of letters) for all 40+ phonemes, including, where applicable, alternative sounds for graphemes

4AD09D186AD840FC8041E71F6279378A.description: apply phonic knowledge and skills as the route to decode words

7ACE2A77E8534E918183F5A6EB86FCB7.description: select and use appropriate registers for effective communication

88DD3559EE9D4F6E891A9D0CC373487E.description: consider and evaluate different viewpoints, attending to and building on the contributions of others

688B9D0B96BB4FC78264FEF76BC13660.description: gain, maintain and monitor the interest of the listener(s)

69E96888C4464C0893732356C577AABA.description:
participate in discussions, presentations, performances, role play, improvisations and
debates

B4F8F11EC3504DF89E9D3F2E7B73E3D5.description: speak audibly and fluently with an increasing command of Standard English

0D526DA977BF4C3CAA0BA990B6543C29.description: use spoken language to develop understanding through speculating, hypothesising, imagining and exploring ideas

60463E8CD1AA4C73B9A3E6B0D49647A6.description: maintain attention and participate actively in collaborative conversations, staying on topic and initiating and responding to comments

C725BDA75FF14F8B9D830B97F3EC4440.description: give well-structured descriptions, explanations and narratives for different purposes, including for expressing feelings

E62EEF52AAFA4053B9FBA7D85F9B6E7C.description: articulate and justify answers, arguments and opinions

FA304C60006B4DF08A750876E6395F6B.description: use relevant strategies to build their vocabulary

53AC49045F124A85B34B3DDB2BEB7979.description: ask relevant questions to extend their understanding and knowledge

91AEF2E37D434AF9803FF97363DDB230.description: listen and respond appropriately to adults and their peers
